title: The End of the Era of Nuclear Constraints? Two Days to Go Before the New START Treaty Between the US and Russia
summary: According to our station, the only remaining nuclear arms control treaty between the US and Russia, the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START), is scheduled to expire on February 5, 2026. The two sides have yet to reach a renewal or replacement agreement, raising strong concerns among global defense experts about a potential "vacuum" in nuclear force oversight. Reports indicate that once the treaty expires, bilateral on-site verification and data exchange mechanisms will completely cease. Analysis suggests that the US has the capability to increase its deployed nuclear warheads by 110% within months, while Russia could increase them by as much as 60%. This not only signifies a loss of transparency but could also trigger an uncontrollable global arms race in the absence of a dispute resolution mechanism.
fullContent:
# Chief Intelligence Officer - Daily Brief
**Topic**: Latest global political and military news
**Time**: 2026/2/3 20:11

## Situation Overview
Welcome to the Daily News Channel, I'm Joe. Today is February 3, 2026. In the coming hours, I will provide an in-depth analysis of the major military and geopolitical developments that have occurred globally over the past 24 hours. The core keyword for this episode is 'transformation'. First, we must focus on the impending expiration of the New START Treaty, the last line of defense in the US-Russia nuclear arms race, leaving the world facing an unprecedented risk of a nuclear regulatory vacuum. Meanwhile, the Middle East is witnessing a peculiar coexistence of 'maximum pressure' and 'diplomatic engagement': the Trump administration, while deploying a carrier strike group to deter Iran, has also confirmed serious dialogue between the two sides. In Europe, with NATO exercises conducted 'without US participation,' rifts among allies are widening further due to the Greenland policy and defense autonomy issues. Furthermore, defense cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region is being rapidly restructured, from the resumption of search and rescue exercises between South Korea and Japan to military cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region, indicating a significant escalation in geopolitical competition. Please see the detailed reports below.

## Key Intelligence
### 1. The End of the Era of Nuclear Constraints? Two Days to Go Before the New START Treaty Between the US and Russia
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: Malay Mail, Newsgram
- **Summary**: According to our station, the only remaining nuclear arms control treaty between the US and Russia, the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START), is scheduled to expire on February 5, 2026. The two sides have yet to reach a renewal or replacement agreement, raising strong concerns among global defense experts about a potential "vacuum" in nuclear force oversight. Reports indicate that once the treaty expires, bilateral on-site verification and data exchange mechanisms will completely cease. Analysis suggests that the US has the capability to increase its deployed nuclear warheads by 110% within months, while Russia could increase them by as much as 60%. This not only signifies a loss of transparency but could also trigger an uncontrollable global arms race in the absence of a dispute resolution mechanism.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Malay Mail](https://www.malaymail.com/news/world/2026/02/03/what-the-new-start-nuclear-treaty-is-and-why-its-expiry-could-reshape-global-nuclear-limits/207705)
  - [2] [Newsgram](https://www.newsgram.com/america/2026/02/03/us-russia-nuclear-treaty-expires)

### 2. Frequent diplomatic signals from the US and Iran have been exchanged, with Trump confirming that the two sides are engaged in "serious dialogue."
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: CGTN, 路透社
- **Summary**: According to CGTN and several international media outlets, US President Trump recently confirmed that the US and Iran are engaged in "serious dialogue" regarding a new security agreement, marking the first direct diplomatic contact since April 2026. Iranian senior official Larijani also stated that negotiations are progressing actively. Trump explicitly demanded that any new agreement must include Iran halting its production of highly enriched uranium and strictly curbing its ballistic missile program. Despite this diplomatic glimmer of hope, the uncertainty surrounding the deal has caused WTI crude oil prices to fluctuate, briefly falling below $62 per barrel. The market is closely watching whether the negotiations can lead to a long-term de-escalation of geopolitical tensions.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CGTN](https://www.cgtn.com/world/middle-east.html)
  - [2] [路透社](https://www.rttnews.com/3613901/crude-oil-skyrockets-amid-imminent-war-threat-in-middle-east.aspx?type=cdt)

### 3. While negotiating, the US military is also exerting pressure: deploying the USS Abraham Lincoln carrier strike group to the Middle East to carry out deterrence.
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: 德干先驱报, Madhyamam Online
- **Summary**: According to our observations, while diplomatic negotiations between the US and Iran have taken place, the US military deployment in the Middle East has not been relaxed. According to the Deccan Herald, the US has deployed a large carrier fleet centered on the USS Abraham Lincoln, along with several destroyers and elite fighter jets, to the Persian Gulf and surrounding waters. Analysts point out that this "carrot and stick" strategy aims to increase the US's leverage at the negotiating table through maximum military pressure. Currently, the US military is on high alert in the region, designed to respond to any possible contingencies and ensure that its proposed security agreement demands are taken seriously by Iran.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Deccan Herald](https://www.deccanherald.com/news_sitemap.xml)
  - [2] [Madhyamam Online](https://madhyamamonline.com/amp/world/iran-ready-fair-and-equitable-talks-us-says-president-1491785)

### 4. Trump announces 25% punitive tariffs on Iranian trade, further escalating his isolation tactics.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: 纽约时报 (NYT), Trading Economics
- **Summary**: According to The New York Times, the Trump administration recently announced a major economic sanctions policy: imposing a 25% punitive tariff on any country trading with Iran. Reports indicate that this move aims to completely isolate Iran economically and cut off its access to foreign exchange. Currently, global supply chains have begun to react, with companies in many countries urgently assessing trade risks related to Iran. This strategy, combined with the current US military deterrence, forms the two pillars of the Trump administration's Iran policy, intended to force Tehran to make substantial concessions in nuclear agreement negotiations through extreme economic pressure.
- **References**:
  - [1] [NYT](https://www.nytimes.com/)
  - [2] [Trading Economics](https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/brent-crude-oil/news/522351)

### 5. The US and India reach a key agreement: India abandons Russian oil purchases and turns to US-Venezuela energy supplies.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: MacroMicro, 纽约时报
- **Summary**: According to our sources, amidst US tariff pressure on Iranian trade, the US and India reached a landmark energy and trade agreement. Under the agreement, India agreed to halt purchases of Russian oil and instead increase energy imports from the US and Venezuela. In return, the US significantly reduced tariffs on Indian goods from 25% to 18%. This move is widely seen as a key US tool for reshaping the global geopolitical landscape, aiming to weaken the energy export revenues of Russia and Iran while consolidating the strategic partnership between the US and India.
- **References**:
  - [1] [MacroMicro](https://en.macromicro.me/quickie)
  - [2] [NYT](https://www.nytimes.com/)

### 6. Iranian military responds strongly: If attacked, all Israeli military bases will be targeted.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: Mehr News (MNA)
- **Summary**: According to Iran's Mehr News Agency, a senior general of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard recently issued a stern warning. He pointed out that Iran's current armed capabilities have far surpassed those during the "12-Day War." If Israel dares to launch any form of attack against Iran, the Iranian military will swiftly target and strike all military bases and core facilities within Israel. The general emphasized that Iran is prepared to carry out a "regrettable retaliation." This statement further escalates tensions in the Middle East, demonstrating that Tehran, despite facing diplomatic pressure, maintains a very high level of military resolve.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Mehr News Agency](https://en.mehrnews.com/news/241351/Iran-to-keep-eye-on-all-Zionist-regime-s-centers-if-attacked)

### 7. Analysis predicts the probability of a US-Iran conflict has risen to 75%, with Iran facing a critical point of military pressure.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: Jewish News Syndicate, Bitget
- **Summary**: According to our station, several senior geopolitical analysts point out that Iran is currently approaching a tipping point in terms of withstanding external military pressure. Influenced by recent leaks of Iran's overseas assassination plans and escalating internal divisions, the probability of a US military strike against Iran is considered to have risen to 75%. Energy analysts warn that recent fluctuations in oil prices have begun to reflect this potential risk of supply disruptions. Meanwhile, the Israel Defense Forces have also publicly stated that they are prepared to launch a series of operations on all fronts, meaning that the risk of a larger-scale conflict in the Middle East is significantly accumulating.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Jewish News Syndicate](https://www.jns.org/)
  - [2] [Bitget News](https://www.bitget.com/news/detail/12560605175263)

### 8. The Rafah border crossing has reopened to a limited extent, marking a shift in the Gaza landscape under a fragile ceasefire agreement.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: 纽约时报, DW
- **Summary**: According to reports from Deutsche Welle and The New York Times, the Rafah crossing has recently been allowed limited passage for the first time since Israel occupied it in May 2024. Reports indicate that some Gaza patients in urgent need of medical treatment have been allowed to leave the country. While this move is seen as part of implementing the fragile ceasefire agreement and has brought an increase in humanitarian aid, the situation remains highly tense. Recent Israeli attacks have resulted in the deaths of more than 30 Palestinians, and Israel has emphasized that it will continue searching for the remains of hostages in Gaza. The United Nations has warned that the humanitarian crisis in the region has not fundamentally eased.
- **References**:
  - [1] [NYT](https://www.nytimes.com/)
  - [2] [DW](https://www.dw.com/en/latest-videos/s-62391524)

### 9. The United States approved a $15.7 billion arms sale to strengthen the defenses of Israel and Saudi Arabia.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: CGTN
- **Summary**: According to CGTN, the US government has formally approved a massive $15.7 billion arms sale, targeting Israel and Saudi Arabia. This move aims to strengthen the defense capabilities of these regional allies in the face of potential regional conflicts. Notably, while accepting US-made weapons, Saudi Arabia is also seeking to deepen its defense cooperation with Pakistan. Analysts believe that Saudi Arabia's move is intended to address potential uncertainties in US policy and the increasingly complex geopolitical landscape in the Middle East through diversified military diplomacy.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CGTN](https://www.cgtn.com/world)

### 10. The 2026 Paris Summit concludes: 26 countries sign a long-term security guarantee agreement for Ukraine.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: YouTube-Global Pact
- **Summary**: According to our correspondent in Paris, the 2026 Paris Summit officially concluded yesterday, with leaders from 35 countries reaching important consensus on a post-conflict security framework for Ukraine. Among them, 26 countries formally signed a "Global Post-Conflict Security Guarantee Agreement," aimed at providing multilateral military, economic, and diplomatic support to post-conflict Ukraine. This agreement establishes a new logic of collective defense, focusing not only on current military assistance but also on building long-term regional stability. This is seen as a significant turning point in the 2026 international security architecture, marking a return to multilateralism in addressing complex conflicts.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Paris Summit 2026](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eUShzxhg4ck)

### 14. Trump's Greenland policy sparks diplomatic turmoil; Greenland's prime minister warns of threats to Arctic security.
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: ICRT, Simple Flying
- **Summary**: According to our station, US President Trump recently reiterated his intention to control Greenland and harshly criticized the defense spending targets of NATO allies. This move quickly triggered a strong backlash within NATO. Greenlandic Prime Minister Nielsen issued a statement publicly warning that this move would seriously threaten the traditional security architecture in the Arctic region. Meanwhile, this diplomatic friction has begun to affect actual military cooperation, with political leaders from several countries stating that uncertainty about US strategic intentions is prompting European allies to reassess their defense spending and procurement plans within the NATO framework.
- **References**:
  - [1] [ICRT](https://www.icrt.com.tw/info_list01.php?&mlevel1=6&mlevel2=12)
  - [2] [Simple Flying](https://simpleflying.com/why-us-worried-canada-order-new-f-35-jets/)

### 15. Canada's F-35 procurement intentions have wavered, with the Swedish Saab fighter jet becoming a key alternative.
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: Simple Flying, Bloomberg
- **Summary**: According to Simple Flying, Canada has shown significant hesitation in procuring F-35 fighter jets due to the recent fluctuations in the Trump administration's foreign policy. The report indicates that the Canadian Department of National Defence is reassessing its reliance on a single American defense system, with the Swedish Saab Griffin fighter jet being considered as a potential alternative. US Ambassador to Canada, Hoekstra, has warned that if Canada scales back its F-35 purchases, the US will have to increase its flight frequency in Canadian airspace to fill the defense gaps left by the North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD). This power struggle marks a turning point in traditional US-Canada defense cooperation.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Simple Flying](https://simpleflying.com/why-us-worried-canada-order-new-f-35-jets/)
  - [2] [Bloomberg](https://simpleflying.com/why-us-worried-canada-order-new-f-35-jets/)

### 16. NATO's "No US" exercise tests independent operations; Europe strengthens its drone defenses.
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: Forbes, Reddit
- **Summary**: According to Forbes, in response to the growing threat of hybrid warfare, NATO recently conducted a large-scale military exercise called "Steadfast Dart." A unique aspect of this exercise was its focus on testing the ability of European allies to independently manage crises and conduct coordinated operations in the absence of US support. Simultaneously, in response to the frequent occurrence of hybrid drone attacks, European countries are jointly adjusting their border defense strategies. Analysts point out that with the increasing tension in the strategic relationship between the EU and the US, European countries are accelerating the development of self-reliant defense systems to cope with potential security isolation.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/news_sitemap.xml)
  - [2] [Reddit r/NewColdWar](https://www.reddit.com/r/NewColdWar/)

### 17. China and Russia launch a new round of strategic stability consultations; Türkiye extends its defense reach into Latin America.
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: CGTN, Daily Sabah
- **Summary**: According to CGTN, China and Russia recently held a new round of strategic stability consultations in Beijing, focusing on ways to strengthen military cooperation amid global instability. Meanwhile, Turkey, a NATO member, has shown strong momentum in becoming a defense partner in Latin America. Reports indicate that Turkey is actively promoting its advanced defense technologies to South American countries. These developments suggest that the global defense cooperation system is rapidly evolving from a traditional NATO-centric model towards a more complex multipolar structure.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CGTN](https://www.cgtn.com/world)
  - [2] [Daily Sabah](https://www.dailysabah.com/)

### 19. After a nine-year hiatus, South Korea and Japan announced the resumption of joint naval search and rescue exercises.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: UPI
- **Summary**: According to United Press International (UPI), the South Korean and Japanese governments have reached a significant agreement to resume the naval search and rescue exercise (SAREX), which had been suspended for nine years. The report notes that the resumption of the exercise is seen as a major breakthrough in maritime security cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region. After years of fluctuating bilateral relations, the two countries have re-established a collaborative mechanism in the areas of joint naval operations and humanitarian assistance. Analysts believe this signifies that the trilateral security framework of the US, Japan, and South Korea is becoming closer and more pragmatic in addressing complex regional situations, contributing to improved contingency response capabilities in the region.
- **References**:
  - [1] [UPI](https://www.upi.com/sitemap.xml)

### 20. The memoir of a former army chief of staff has sparked heated debate in the Indian Parliament regarding the Doklam standoff.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: Deccan Herald
- **Summary**: According to the Deccan Herald, a heated debate recently erupted in the Indian Parliament regarding border security strategy. Opposition leader Rahul Gandhi cited an unpublished memoir by former Army Chief of Staff Naravane, detailing little-known military aspects of the 2017 Doklam standoff. This incident has once again brought the issue of India's border territorial sovereignty to the forefront. The report points out that the memoir's contents have prompted a reassessment of national security policy in the context of the current Sino-Indian standoff, highlighting significant strategic divisions within India regarding how to address border challenges.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Deccan Herald](https://www.deccanherald.com/news_sitemap.xml)

### 21. The Pentagon is advancing its MACH-TB 2.0 program to accelerate hypersonic testing using commercial vehicles.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: Aero-News Network
- **Summary**: According to Aviation News, the U.S. Department of Defense has officially launched the third phase of its Hypersonic Test Vehicle (MACH-TB 2.0) program. The report states that Stratolaunch and Varda Space Industries have been awarded Pentagon contracts to provide advanced air-launch capabilities and reusable reentry vehicles, respectively. This move aims to leverage mature technologies from the private sector to increase testing frequency and significantly reduce development costs, thereby accelerating the iteration and deployment of U.S. military hypersonic weapon hardware. This signifies the U.S. military's deep integration of a "commercialization model" into advanced weapons development.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Aero-News Network](https://www.aero-news.net/index.cfm?do=main.textpost&id=367A70F0-D4F1-4246-BC74-62205F70AB86)

### 22. The UK, assuming the rotating presidency of the Security Council, is focusing this month on multilateral conflict mediation.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: Security Council Agenda - UK Presidency
- **Summary**: According to the UN News Centre, James Kariuki, Chargé d'Affaires of the UK delegation, recently released the UN Security Council's agenda for February 2026. As the rotating president for this month, the UK plans to launch a series of diplomatic initiatives, focusing on multilateral conflict resolution and the development of international security norms. Reports indicate that the UK aims to coordinate consensus among Security Council members on maintaining the multilateral system, particularly against the backdrop of frequent geopolitical crises and pressure to reform existing international institutions, seeking a common denominator of security rules acceptable to all parties.
- **References**:
  - [1] [UN News](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HfeHbMbDg1g)

### 23. The EU is holding a "2026 Reconciliation Conference" to discuss defense cooperation and trade resilience.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: EU Leaders Unite On Security And Trade Strategies
- **Summary**: According to a report from Brussels by this station, EU leaders recently held a thematic meeting entitled "Stocktaking 2026." The core of the meeting was strengthening EU security, trade, and global competitiveness. The leaders emphasized that in the current complex and volatile geopolitical environment, the EU must address transnational threats through a joint security framework and ensure a stronger voice for the European economy within the multilateral trading system. The report points out that the meeting reached several internal strategies aimed at enhancing European defense autonomy and economic resilience, demonstrating the EU's sense of urgency to "stick together" during a period of rising strategic uncertainty.
- **References**:
  - [1] [EU News](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zJP87xS7Q_E)

### 24. The United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (OOSA) opened a meeting focusing on the responsible application of AI in space exploration.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: UNOOSA
- **Summary**: According to a report from Vienna, the 63rd session of the Science and Technology Subcommittee of the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA) officially opened yesterday. This 12-day multilateral meeting will focus on outer space environmental security, the sustainability of space activities, and the responsible application of artificial intelligence in space exploration. Experts from around the world are engaged in in-depth consultations on how to safeguard space assets and develop multilateral governance rules. The meeting is expected to release a series of new guidelines on reducing risks to the space environment and defining responsibilities to ensure the long-term sustainability of space activities.
- **References**:
  - [1] [UNOOSA](https://www.unoosa.org/)

### 25. Germany has arrested five members of a smuggling ring suspected of illegally exporting goods to Russian defense companies.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: Pamfleti (Reuters)
- **Summary**: According to Reuters, German federal prosecutors recently conducted raids, arresting five suspects for allegedly violating sanctions. Investigations revealed that the group organized over 16,000 illicit shipments since 2022, exporting embargoed goods worth approximately $36 million to Russian defense companies. German intelligence agencies believe these procurement activities were directly directed by Russian state institutions. This arrest highlights Europe's firm stance on enforcing sanctions against Russia and reveals the complex network of shadow supply chains that persists even in military conflicts.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Pamfleti/Reuters](https://pamfleti.net/english/bota/trump-flet-per-lajme-te-mira-putin-bombardon-kievin-dhe-kharkivin-cfare-ndo-i319770)

### 26. Reports indicate that the US military budget will increase to $1.5 trillion in 2027, setting a new record.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: MacroMicro
- **Summary**: According to market rumors cited by MacroMicro, cited by our financial channel, the US government is considering a significant increase in its 2027 military budget to $1.5 trillion. If this proposal is passed, it will break the record for US defense spending. The report analyzes that the budget surge will primarily be used to accelerate the deployment of hypersonic weapons, strengthen military infrastructure in the Pacific region, and enhance the application of artificial intelligence in combat systems. Furthermore, defense procurement officials are attempting to use economic means to support the implementation of military strategy by reviewing trade plans aimed at resetting multilateral relations.
- **References**:
  - [1] [MacroMicro](https://en.macromicro.me/quickie)

### 27. Reports indicate that a U.S. Navy rear admiral resigned in protest against policy changes, raising questions about the Pentagon's internal executive capabilities.
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: Facebook, Simpleflying
- **Summary**: According to our sources, recent reports circulating on social media and in some industry media outlets indicate that a U.S. Navy rear admiral resigned after refusing to execute orders to conduct military attacks involving civilian areas. Reports suggest this rumor has garnered widespread attention since Hergész took office as Defense Secretary under the Trump administration, hinting at a potential serious division within the Pentagon between policy implementation and ethical boundaries. While there has been no official comment, such reports have fueled ongoing speculation about the stability of the U.S. Department of Defense leadership and the direction of its future operational policies.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Facebook Group](https://www.facebook.com/groups/215155240781012/posts/1185365670426626/)

### 28. Albania's state-owned arms company expands recruitment in an effort to enhance its international competitiveness in the arms trade.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: Scan TV
- **Summary**: According to Albania's Scan TV, the country's state-owned arms production and trading company, KAYO, recently announced plans to create 326 new jobs, aiming to significantly expand its production capacity for weapons, ammunition, and various military equipment. Company officials stated that they are currently strengthening personnel security and confidentiality vetting standards to meet the demands of higher-standard international orders. This move not only aims to boost local employment through increased exports but also reflects the efforts of small Balkan nations to gain a foothold in the international defense market amidst the current global surge in arms demand.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Scan TV](https://scantv.al/english/)

### 29. The Canadian Department of National Defence has issued a large-scale tender covering services ranging from solid-state shredders to radar antennas.
- **Time**: 2026-02-02
- **Source**: CanadaBuys
- **Summary**: According to the Canadian government's official tendering platform, the Department of National Defence (DND) recently issued several tender notices covering a wide range of supplies and services. These include the procurement of specialized solid-state shredders, valve parts supply, and radar antenna dismantling and disposal services. Furthermore, management services for Canadian military academies are also among the tenders. Analysts point out that this series of detailed procurements reflects Canada's commitment to maintaining the operational effectiveness of its existing military assets and ensuring its logistics system provides robust support in a volatile security environment through refined material updates and infrastructure management.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CanadaBuys](https://canadabuys.canada.ca/en/tender-opportunities)

### 30. The Indo-Pacific partnership continues to deepen, and multilateral cooperation frameworks address maritime security challenges.
- **Time**: 2026-02-03
- **Source**: The Hans India
- **Summary**: According to the Indian newspaper Hans, the latest diplomatic and security developments indicate that partnerships in the Indo-Pacific region are undergoing a further strategic upgrade. Multiple countries are committed to jointly addressing territorial disputes and maritime security challenges by enhancing security cooperation within bilateral and multilateral frameworks. The report emphasizes that this strengthened partnership extends beyond joint exercises, delving into intelligence sharing and the transfer of key technologies. This is seen as a clear manifestation of regional countries achieving "collective self-protection" by building a closer, networked cooperative system in the face of external pressure.
- **References**:
  - [1] [The Hans India](https://www.thehansindia.com/news-sitemap-daily.xml)
